byline.original: By REBECCA R. RUIZ and MICHAEL SCHWIRTZ

abstract: Grigory Rodchenkov, former director of Russia's antidoping laboratory, says dozens of Russian athletes at 2014 Winter Olympics in Sochi, Russia, including at least 15 medal winners, were involved in state-run doping program; says shadow lab was used to replace tainted urine samples with clean bottles for testing as part of effort to gain dominance at Games; account highlights what appears to be one of elaborate doping schemes in sports history.
lead_paragraph: Each night, said the director of the antidoping lab at the Sochi Games, bottles of urine were passed through a hole in the wall and replaced for testing the next day.

headline.main: Russian Insider Says State-Run Doping Fueled Olympic Gold
headline.print_headline: An Insider in Sochi Tells How Russia Beat Doping Tests
